snippet: Regulators are noting new abuses tied to reverse mortgages, which let people 62 and older borrow money against the value of their homes and not pay it back until they move out or die.
abstract: Federal and state regulators report increasing abuse tied to reverse mortgages, which are designed to allow seniors to stay in their homes; under scrutiny are smaller mortgage brokers, including former subprime lenders, that flooded the market after the recent exit of big banks; Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is working on rules that could mean better disclosure for consumers and stricter supervision of such lenders.
lead_paragraph: Regulators are noting new abuses tied to reverse mortgages, which let people 62 and older borrow money against the value of their homes and not pay it back until they move out or die.

headline.seo: Reverse Mortgages Costing Some Older Americans Their Homes
headline.main: A Risky Lifeline for the Elderly Is Costing Some Their Homes
headline.print_headline: Abuse Growing In Loan Option For the Elderly
